block.p: After decades of rejection, Danny Biasone, the bowling alley proprietor from Syracuse, who invented professional basketball's 24-second shot clock, was finally elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame last week.

Biasone, who owned the Syracuse Nationals from 1946 until 1963, created the shot clock in 1954 in an attempt to speed up the pro game, which had been suffering from low scoring and dwindling popularity.

After decades of rejection, Danny Biasone, the bowling alley proprietor from Syracuse, who invented professional basketball's 24-second shot clock, was finally elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame last week.

Biasone, who owned the Syracuse Nationals from 1946 until 1963, created the shot clock in 1954 in an attempt to speed up the pro game, which had been suffering from low scoring and dwindling popularity.
Introduced in the National Basketball Association's 1954-55 season, the 24-second clock revived both scoring and attendance in the fledgling league. Biasone died in 1992.
